place_of_publication.other_info_on_pub: * Crum’s drymocallis or wood beauty E

taxon_identification.taxon_hierarchy: family rosaceae;subfamily rosoideae;tribe potentilleae;genus drymocallis;species pseudorupestris;variety crumiana

bio:treatment.description: Stems (0.3–)0.8–2(–2.5) dm, base 1–2 mm diam., short hairs absent or sparse. Basal leaves (2–)3–9(–15) cm, not to sparsely short-hairy, sparsely to moderately subsessile golden glandular, rigidly bristly (bristles 0.5–1 mm); leaflet pairs 3–4(–5); terminal leaflet broadly obovate to flabellate, 0.2–1.2(–2) × 0.5–1.5 cm, teeth ± single, 2–5 per side. Pedicels 5–12 (proximal to 20) mm, bristly, short hairs absent or sparse. Flowers 2–8; hypanthia and sepals prominently bristly, bristles 1–1.5 mm; epicalyx bractlets elliptic-ovate to lanceolate, 2–3.5(–4) × 1–2 mm; sepals 4–6(–7) mm; petals not or scarcely overlapping, often red-tinged, narrowly to broadly obovate, 5–7(–9) × 3–5 mm; filaments 1.5–2(–3) mm; styles usually dark red, rarely golden brown.
rocky slopes talus and ledges on metamorphic granitic and volcanic substrates
bio:treatment.discussion: The red-tinged petals of var. crumiana, initially noted by E. Crum (as summarized by B. Ertter 2007), are not reliably diagnostic; however, the distinctive leaflet aspect is not found elsewhere in Drymocallis, though approaching D. fissa in Colorado. The vestiture includes prominent golden glands and conspicuous bristles that are rarely found in other North American Drymocallis, and the stigmas are commonly (though not consistently) dark reddish, not the more common pale golden brown. The variety occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada in Fresno, Inyo, and Tulare counties, and in the White Mountains of Mono County.
